column16: One detected Issue message I didn’t see was something that may be needed when screening was not actually completed due to a lack of a variable.  The clinician could mistakenly think screening took place and there was no problem found. An example may be where a patient’s dosing wasn’t screened because we may have their age but not weight  - this could happen in an ED where the patient is unconscious or in a retail pharmacy where weight isn’t typically recorded. The pharmacist may input a high dose for a pediatric patient but never receive an alert because weight wasn’t present. I will make a comment to that affect but otherwise found the detected issues to be good.
column17: **website comment**

column16:
o Should QICore comment on ClinicalReasoning resources, such as GuidanceResponse and PlanDefinition?  Perhaps profiles do not make sense because they are not part of QUICK, but it seems like QICore should provide implementors at least some guidance on how ClinicalReasoning relates, since it is also focused on decision support and quality measures.
o I do not understand why an element where MustSupport is false could not be used for triggering a CDS action if it's available.  A more detailed example of why this is the case might help.
o Why require a CDS service to support a profile if the resource has no relevence to type of decision support being provided?  Do all CDS services need to support QICore-Claim?

column14: QICore FHIR profiles provide a physical model for core elements of the Quality Information and Clinical Knowledge (QUICK) logical model. The QUICK model, derived from QICore, provides a uniform way for clinical decision support and quality measures to refer to clinical data. Simultaneously, the QICore profiles provide a physical implementation of QUICK, making data for quality improvement applications accessible via the FHIR interface. However, using FHIR in the physical layer is optional. If the QICore FHIR profiles are not used at the physical layer, the implementer is responsible for mapping their data directly into the QUICK model via their own customized data access layer.
column16: Please note that the QUICK model is now deprecated in favor of CIMI. The documentation should make this clear to the reader in the introduction.
column17: Please note that the QUICK model is now deprecated in favor of CIMI. The documentation should make this clear to the reader in the introduction.

column14: The proposed unified model is known as QUICK. QUICK is a logical model consisting of objects, attributes, and relationships. QUICK provides a uniform way for clinical decision support and quality measures to refer to clinical data. Authors of future quality measures and clinical decision support artifacts may use QUICK, together with the Clinical Quality Language (CQL), to create interoperable and executable knowledge artifacts.
column16: The documentation should probably be modified to indicate that QUICK has been deprecated in favor of CIMI. The QUICK model is no longer maintained and as such will not be evolving. On the other hand, CIMI continues to evolve.
column17: The documentation should probably be modified to indicate that QUICK has been deprecated in favor of CIMI. The QUICK model is no longer maintained and as such will not be evolving. On the other hand, CIMI continues to evolve.

column14: For the CIMI effort in particular, the QICore effort is engaged in the same work to identify and develop tooling to automatically generate FHIR profiles from a logical model, ideally resulting in a scenario where the CIMI modeling tools can be used to express the QUICK logical model, and then use the same tool chain to generate the QICore profiles, rather than infer the QUICK model from the definition of the QICore profiles as is currently done.
column16: My recommendation would be to introduce this early in the document. For instance, stating that QICore profiles are based on QUICK and that QUICK will be superceded by CIMI in the near future.
column17: My recommendation would be to introduce this early in the document. For instance, stating that QICore profiles are based on QUICK and that QUICK will be superceded by CIMI in the near future.

column16: The CIMI WG would like to work with the CDS and CQI working groups to incorporate the requirements surfaced by QI Core and US Core into CIMI and to generate future quality profiles from CIMI models directly. Maintaining QICore profiles by hand is probably not a viable option in the long term.
column17: The CIMI WG would like to work with the CDS and CQI working groups to incorporate the requirements surfaced by QI Core and US Core into CIMI and to generate future quality profiles from CIMI models directly. Maintaining QICore profiles by hand is probably not a viable option in the long term.

column14: Encounter.principal diagnosis
column16: Clinical quality measures need to address the concept of a Principal Diagnosis defined by statute as the coded diagnosis/problem established after study to be chiefly responsible for occasioning the admission of the patient to the hospital for care. The roles provided do not directly address principal diagnosis. FHIR tracker (https://gforge.hl7.org/gf/project/fhir/tracker/?action=TrackerItemEdit&tracker_item_id=10544) suggest that encounter-primaryDiagnosis and encounter-relatedCondition extensions will be removed as they are redundant with the core resource (using Encounter,diagnosis.role and Encounter.diagnosis.rank.  Recommend mapping QDM Encounter attribute "principal diagnosis" to Encounter.diagnosis.role (role = discharge diagnosis OR billing diagnosis) with Encounter.diagnosis.rank = 1 to enable clinical quality measures and clinical decision support.
column17: Clinical quality measures need to address the concept of a Principal Diagnosis defined by statute as the coded diagnosis/problem established after study to be chiefly responsible for occasioning the admission of the patient to the hospital for care. The roles provided do not directly address principal diagnosis. FHIR tracker (https://gforge.hl7.org/gf/project/fhir/tracker/?action=TrackerItemEdit&tracker_item_id=10544) suggest that encounter-primaryDiagnosis and encounter-relatedCondition extensions will be removed as they are redundant with the core resource (using Encounter,diagnosis.role and Encounter.diagnosis.rank.  Recommend mapping QDM Encounter attribute "principal diagnosis" to Encounter.diagnosis.role (role = discharge diagnosis OR billing diagnosis) with Encounter.diagnosis.rank = 1 to enable clinical quality measures and clinical decision support.

column16: QDM does not include a context attribute to indicate the intent for when the prescribed (requested) medication should be given/taken. MedicationRequest.context FHIR metadata element is confusing and potentially ambiguous.  Epic has a field "mode" that indicates when a requested medication should be administered/given. The field is often used in the inpatient setting for medication eprescriptions sent to the outpatient pharmacy for patients to pick up after hospital discharge. The MedicationRequest.context field seems to indicate the Encounter during which the request occurs, but it should be addressed when the request should reflect administration of the requested medication. If that assumption is incorrect, the context description should be clarified and a new metadata element should address when the medication requested should be administered.
column17: Suggest reconciling the MedicationRequest.context metadata element with FHIR and mapping QDM to the attribute determine appropriate. Also recommend update to QDM to allow expression of eCQMs that address medication request context. Examples include inpatient measures that address orders intended to be filled in the post-discharge outpatient setting.  Note - this request is not to eliminate the QDM element requesting the discharge medication list which has additional value.

column16: Update the QDM to QI Core map (and QI Core) to address changes to FHIR US Core - for example, US Core specifies how vital signs should be expressed. QI Core and QDM Physical Exam Performed currently map all physical exam findings as observations. The specification needs to specifically call out elements that have more granular definition in US Core.
column17: Update the QDM to QI Core map (and QI Core) to address changes to FHIR US Core - for example, US Core specifies how vital signs should be expressed. The specification needs to specifically call out elements that have more granular definition in US Core.

column14: As a U.S. Realm product, QICore recommends value sets and vocabularies required by Meaningful Use. US Core provides the FHIR realization of these requirements. Because QICore is expected to be applied outside the U.S. Realm, and also in clinical settings where local terminologies exist, U.S. Realm bindings are preferred but not required in the QICore profiles. When and if Meaningful Use adopts QICore, QUICK, and CQL, policy could be created that could mandate the preferred bindings given in the standard.
column15: As a US Realm product, QICore requires value sets and vocabularies referenced in the ONC Common Clinical Data Set (CCDS) and the US Core Data for Interoperability. Because  QICore is expected to be applied outside the U.S. Realm, and also in clinical settings where local terminologies exist, U.S. Realm bindings could be  accompanied by alternative codes as translation codes in the QICore profiles. In the case that the US Core Data for Interoperability adopts QICore, QUICK, and CQL, policy should be created that could mandate the preferred bindings given in the standard.
column16: Recommend updated references for US federal policy. Also suggest that QICore implement required bindings for at elast some datatyeps. Given that it is a US Realm standard it is much more useful in FHIR with a clear terminology binding.
column17: Recommend updated references for US federal policy. Also suggest that QICore implement required bindings for at elast some datatyeps. Given that it is a US Realm standard it is much more useful in FHIR with a clear terminology binding.

column16: I'd like to understand better how the terminology bindings and value sets associatd in the profiles will affect quality measure artifacts in the future.  For example, the QI Core profile for medication has a terminology binding for medication.code that has an enormous RxNorm value set associated with it.  As a measure developer, how will the medication value set included in my measure artifact be affected by this terminology binding?  Will the value set included in the measure be viewed as a constraint on the bound value set?
column17: I'd like to understand better how the terminology bindings and value sets associatd in the profiles will affect quality measure artifacts in the future.  For example, the QI Core profile for medication has a terminology binding for medication.code that has an enormous RxNorm value set associated with it.  As a measure developer, how will the medication value set included in my measure artifact be affected by this terminology binding?
